SECTION 4.00 - GENERAL PROVISIONS
A. Wherever any subdivision of land shall hereafter be °laid out wii:hin
the incorporated limits of the Village of Itasca, or within contiguous
territory not more than one and one half (l-1/2) miles beyo~q the
incorporated boundaries of the Vi11age of Itasca, the subdivider
thereof or his agent shall submi't both a preli:ninar/ 'plan and a final
subdivision plat to the Village of !'tasca for its approval. The
subdivision plats and all procedures relating thereto shall in all
respects be in full compliance with these regulations.
8. Until preliminary plans and plats fer the subdivision are approved:
1. No land shall-be subdivided, nor any street laid out, nor any
improvement~m~de to the natural land.
2.
3.
No lot, l~a~t or parcel of land within any subdivision shall be
offered ror,'safe. nor shall an; sale, contract for sale, or
option be mide'~r given.
No improvements--such as sidewalks, water supply, storm water
drainage, sanitary sewerage facilities, gas service, electric
service, lighting, grading, paving or surfacing of streets -
shall hereafter be made by any owner or owners or his or their
agent.
c. No land shall be subdivfded for an'/'use' whicr{~{i: determined by the
Plan Commission after investigation_ by the Vill'a:ge tn;ineer to be
located within areas 6f special flood, hazard until the subdivjder has
complied with the Village of Itasca, lllinois Hunicfpal Code and/or
Engineering Standards and Specifications.
D. No land shall be subdivided for any use which is determined by the
Plan Commission after investigation by the Village Engineer, to be
unsuitable for such a use by reason of flooding or bad drainage,
adverse earth and rock formation or topography, or any other features
likely to be harmful to the health, safety or welfare of the future
residents in the proposed s"bdivision or of the community.
Unsuitable land located within areas of special flood hazard as
identified in the Municipal Code, shall be s_ubject to the provisions
of that Ordinance.
Unsuitable land located outside areas of special flood hazard may be
subdivided only if the subdivider agrees to make improvements which
~ill, in the opinion of the Village Ensineer, make the area safe for
occupancy and provide adequate lot and street drainage and storm water
detention facilites.
3.
E. Where the developer or subdivider of land outside areas of special
flood hazard can show in writing and with appropriate documentation
that the strict adherence to the design standards set forth causes an
unnecessary hardship, the Village Board may approve a variance. Such
variance may be granted after recommendation by the Plan Commission
and where topography and conditions peculiar to the site or
surrounding area substantiates a variance without destroyin9 the
intent of the provisions of this Ordinance.
Variances for land within areas of special flood hazard shall be
subject to the provisions of the Municipal Code.
F. All dedications of land and offerings in-lieu-of to the Village for
use as streets, highways, alleys, schools, parks, playgrounds or other
public uses shall be referred to the Plan Commission for review and
recommendation before being accepted by the Village Board or by any
other governing authority of the Village of Itasca.
G. Where a tract of land proposed for a subdivision is part of a larger,
logical subdivision unit in relation to the Village as a whole, the
Plan Commission may, before recommending approval, request that the
subdivider submit a plan for the entire area or neighborhood to be
used by the Plan Commission as an aid in j~dging the proposed plat •..
4.01 INTERPRETATION
A. MinimunvStandards Established. In their interpretation and
application, the provisions of this Ordinance shall be held to be the
minimum requirements for the promotion of the public health, safety,
and general welfare.
B. Higher Standards Govern. Where the conditions imposed by any
provisions of this Ordinance upon the subdivision of land are either
more restrictive or less restrictive than comparable conditions
imposed by any other provisions of this Ordinance or any other
applicable law, ordinance, resolution, rule or resulation of any kind,
the regulations which are more restrictive and impose higher standards
or requirements shall govern.
C. Easements or Covenants not Abrogated. This Ordinance is not intendeJ
to abrogate any easement, covenant, or any other private agreement,
provided that where the re9LJlations of this Ordinance are more
restrictive or impose higher standards or regulations that such
easement, covenant, or other private agreement, the requir:ments of
this Ordinance shall govern.
4.
D. Existing Subdivisions. No subdivision of land, which was not lawfully
existing at the time of the adoption o·f this Ordinance, shall be made
lawful solely by reason of the adoption of this Ordinance; and to the
extent that said subdivision of land is in conflict in any manner with
the requirements of this Ordinance, said subdivision of·lana·remains
unlawful hereunder.
4.02 - SEPARAdlLITY
It is hereby declared to be the intention of the Village Board of the Viilage
of Itasca that the several provisions of this Ordindnce be separable in
accordance with the following:
A. Separability of Parts. If any court of competent jurisdiction shall
adjudge invalid the application of any provision of this Ordinance to
be invalid, such ·judgement shall not affect any other provision of
this Ordinance not specifically included in said judgement.
a. Separability cf Application. If an; court of competent jurisdiction
shall adjudge invalid the application of any provision of this
Ordinance to a particular subdivision of land, such judgement shall
not affect the application of said provision to any other subdivision
of land, not specifically included in said judgement.
5.
SECTION 5.00 - RULES AND DEFINITIONS
In the interpretation of this Ordinance, the rules and definitions contained in
this Section shall be observed and applied, except when the context ~!early
indicates otherwise.
5.0l - RULES
The language set forth in the text of this Ordinance shall be interpreted in
accordance with the following rules of construction:
A. Words used in the present tense shall include the future, the words
used in the singular number shall include the plural number, and the
plural the singular.
B. The word "shall" is mandatory and not discretionary.
C. The word "may" is permissive.
D. The word "1 ot" sila 11 include the words "plot", and "piece", and
"parcel".
E. The phrase "used for" shall include the phrases "arranged for",
"designed for", "intended for", "maintained for", and "occupied for."
5.02 - DEFINITIONS
ADT. Average Daily Traffic
ALLEY. The right-of-way which affords secondary means of access to properties
abutting upon a street.
APPLICANT. The owner or contract purchaser of land proposed to be subdivided
or his legal representative.
APRON. An extension of a driveway lying between the public sid-::walk (or tile
right-of-way line if there is no sidewalkj and the curb and gutters of a
street. The maintenance responsibility for this facility normally being with
the owner of the driveway so extended.
BLOCK. A block is a tract of land bounded by street rights-of-waj, or by a
combination of street rights-of-way and public parks, cemeteries, railroad and
utility rights-of-way, bulkhead lines or shore lines of waterways, or corporate
boundary 1 Ines.
6.
BOND. Any form of security approved as to form by the Village Attorney
including a cash deposit, surety bond, letter of credit, collateral or
instrument of credit in an amount or form accepted by the Board of Trustees.
BORINGS, SOIL. Examination and analysis of the subsoil conditions of a
specific parcel of land by drilling.
BUILDING. Is a structure, with a permanent roof, separated on all sides from
adjacent open space by exterior or party walls, built for the support, shelter,
or enclosure of persons, animals, chattels, or immovable property of any kind,
and which is permanently affixed to the ground.
BUILDING PERMIT. A permit issued by the Village of Itasca for the
construction, erection, or alteration of a structure or building.
BUILDING SETBACK LINE. A line parallel to the street ri;ht-of-wa1 line at a
distance from it, required by the front 1ard requirements of the Itasca Zoning
Ordinance.
COMPREHENSIVE PLAN. The composite of the functional and geographic elements of
the Offical Comprehensive Plan of the Village of Itasca, (adopted October 18,
1977) or any segment thereof, ·;n the fonn of plans, maps, charts, text of
reports, implementing ordinances, and the Official Map.
CORINGS, PAVEMENT. Examination and analysis of the completed surface and/or
sub-surface of a finished pavement by removing a core by dril 1 ing.
CROSSWALK. A public right-of-way located across a block to provide pedestrian
access to adjacent streets·or alleys.
CUL-DE-SAC. A minor street of short len~th, having one end open to traffic and
being permanently terminated at the other end by a vehicular turn-around.
CURB. The permanent edge of a paved surface desiJned to separate the vehicular
travelway from the parkway.
DATUM PLANE. A reference point from which elevations are measured. The datum
plane is a mean sea level as established by the United States Geological Survey
(U.S.G.S.)
DETENTION BASIN. A covered or uncovered reservoir designed to hold an
excessive accumulation of storm water so as to reduce peak flow in an storm
water drainage system.
DEVELOPMENT. Any man-made change to improved or unimproved real property,.
including but not limited to buildings or other structures, mining, dredging,
filling, grading, paving, excavation or drilling operations located within the
area of special flood hazard or elsewhere within the Village of Itasca of i:s
area of planning jurisdiction.
7.
DRAINAGE, SWALE. A turf draina9e ditch of shallow depth with side slopes not
exceeding one to twelve (1-12j feet.
EASEMENT. An authorization or grant by a property owner for the use by another
and for a specific purpose, of any designated part of his property.
ELEVATiONS. The vertical distance measured from a point on the ~round to the
datum plane.
EXCAVATION. Any act of changing of the grade or sub-grade of a tract of land
by cutting, scraping, grading, trenching, digging, filling-in, or otherwise
reshaping the natural contour of the ground.
The following shall not be construed as excavating/filling:
1. Any cutting, grading, trenching, digging, or backfilling of any
foundation of a building approved for construction.
2. Top dressing in an area of existing homes, which top dressing does not
change the drainage patterns.
EXISTING GRADE. The vertical location of the existing ground surface prior to
excavation or filling.
FILL; Any act by which earth, sand, gravel, rock, or any other material is
deposited, placed, replaced, pushed, dumped, pulled, transported or moved to a
new location and shali include the conditions resulting therefrom.
FLOOD EXCAVATiDN BASE. The ~levation in relation to mean sea level of the
crest of the base flood.
FLOOD PLAIN. The land area ad~acent to surface water bodies or waterways that
is subject to periodic inundation when greater than normal water flows are
experienced. The flood plain may be identified according to the frequency of
the flood flow that inundates it. For example, the portion of flood plain
inundated by the flow which is equaled or exceeded once in ten years is the
10-year flood plain. The flood plain inundated by a hundred year storm is the
100-year fiood plain.
FLOODWAY. The channel of a river or other water course and the adjacent land
areas that shall be reserved in order to discharge the base flood water without
cumulatively increasing the water surface elevation more than one-tenth (l/iO)
of one (lj foot.
GRADE. The slope of land, road, street, or other public way expressed in
percent.
8.
GRADIENT OR PERCElff OF GRADE. The vertical rise in feet per one hundred (lOOj
feet of horizontal distance. (A one (1) percent grade is a rise of one (1)
feet in one hundred (100) feet, for example.)
GROSS LAND AREA. The entire area of a development including lots, streets, and
alleys, measured to the center line of any bounding streets.
IMPROVEMENTS. Grading, street surfacing, curbs, gutters, sidewalks, water
mains, fire hydrants, sanitary sewers, storm sewers, culverts, trees, bushes,
landscaping and other additions to the natural state of the land which increase
Its value, utility or habitability in accordance with the provisions of this
Ordinance.
A. Private Improvement - Any installed or constructed facility for which
the responsibility of maintenance and ownership will be retained by
the owner or a homeowners association.
B. Private Common Improvement - Any installed or constructed facility for
which the responsibility of maintenance and ownership will be retained
by the homeowner or condominium association. This includes amenities
such as, swi;nming pools, tennis courts, parks, etc.
C. Public Improvement - Any facility for which the Village of Itasca or
other municipal body may ultimately assume the responsibility for
maintenance and operation or which is constructed for general public
us.e of benefit.
LOT. A tract, plot, or portion of a subdivision or other parcel of land
intended as a unit for the purpose, whether immediate or future of transfer of

lines of such streets does not exceed one hundred thirty-five (135) degrees.

PLANNED DEVELOPMENT. A parcel of land or contiguous parcels of land of a size

and approved by the Village Board of Trustees.
PLAT. A plan, map, or chart of a subdivision of land.
A. Preliminary Plan. A map showing all requisite details of a proposed
subdivision su~nitted to an approving authority for purposes of
preliminary consideration, prepared in conformance with the Plats Act
and Sections 8.02 and 8.03 of this Ordinance.
B. Final Plat. A map of all or part of a subdivision providing
substantial conformance to the Preliminary Plan of a subdivision
prepared in conformance with the requirements of the Plats Act,
Sections 8.05 and 8.06 of this Ordinance and for the recording by the

PROTECTIV£ COVENANTS. Protective covenants are contracts entered into between
private parties and constitute a restriction on the use of all private property
within a subdivision for the benefit of property owners; and to provide mutual
protections against undesirable aspects of development which would tend to
impair stability of values.
RESIDUE AREA. A residue area is that portion of a development not platted as
residential lots or designed for dedication as streets or alleys.
RESUBDIVISION. The relocation of property boundaries, or the re-allocation of
property in a plat of record. The dissolution of property lines not
accompanied by the relocation of new property lines shall not constitwte
resubdivi sion.
RETENTION. A wet bottom storm water storage area that is designed to be
maintained as free water surface or pond.
ROADWAY OR ROAD. Whenever the words, "road" or "roadway" are used in this
Ordinance, it shall be deemed the paved area existing on the street
ri~ht-of-way and not the street ri~ht-of-way width and shall include all curb
and gutter facilities.
ll.
SIDEWALK. That portion of the street or crosswalk way, paved or otherwise
surfaced, intended for pedestrian use only.
SITE. A lot or parcel of land, or a contiguous combination thereof, where
grading work is performed as a single unified operation.
SITE DEVELOPMENT. Altering terrdin and/or vegetation and constructing
driveways.
SOIL TESTING. Determination and anal1sis of the subsoil conditions of a
specific land area by use of soil borings.
STREET. A publicly owned right-of-way which affords primary means of access by
pedestrians and vehicles to abutting properties, whether designated as a
street, avenue, highway, road, boulevard, lane or however otherwise designated.
STREET, COLLECTOR. Streets penetrating neighborhoods which collect traffic
from minor streets in the neighborhood and channel it into the arterial
systems. A minor amount of through-traffic may be carried on and carries local
traffic movements within residential neighborhoods and commerical and
industrial areas.
STREET, MINOR ARTERIAL. Streets and highways interconnecting with and
augmenting the principal arterial system and providing service to trips of
moderate length at a somewhat lower level of travel mobility. The s1stem
places more emphasis on land access ancj distributes travel to geographic areas
smaller than those identified with the principal arterial system. It includes
all arterials not classified as principal.
STREET, MARGINAL ACCESS. A minor street which is parallel and adjacent to
arterial streets and which provides access to abutting properties and
protection to local traffic from fast, through moving traffic on arterial
streets.
STREET, MINOR. Streets not classified in a higher system, providing direct
access to abutting land and access to the higher systems. They offer the
1 owest level of mobii ity an.:! have 1 imited continuity to discourage
through-traffic.
STREET, PRINCIPAL ARTERIAL. Streets and highways serving major metropolitan
activity centers, the highest traffic volume corridors, the longest trip
desires, and a high proportion of total urban area travel on a minimum of
street mileage. Service to abutting land is subordinate to the provisions of
travel service to major traffic movements. This system carries the major
portion of trips enterin9 and leaving the Itasca urban area as well as the
maiority of through movements desiring to bypass the Village.
STREET, PRIVATE. An undedicated street, generally within a Planned Development
which is privately owned or maintained or an easement of access benefiting a
dominant tenant.
12.
STREET, PUBLIC. Any arterial, collector, or minor street which is shown on the
subdivision plat and is or is to be dedicated to public use.

SUBDIVISION. A Planned Development is, for the purposes of this Ordinance, a
subdivision whether or not it is divided into two (2) or more parts. A
subdivision is also the division of land into two (2j or more lots or parcels,
any of which is less that five (5) acres, for the purpose, whether immediate or
future, of transfer of ownership or building development, including a11 public
streets, ways for public service facilities, parks, playgrounds, school
grounds, or other public grounds, and all the tracts, parcels, lots or blocks,
and numbering of all such lots, blucks or parcels by progressive numbers,
giving their precise dimensions. The term subdivision includes resubdivisiun
and, where it is appropridte to the context, relates to the process of
subdividing or to the land subdivided, provided however, that the following
shall not be considered a subdivision and shall be exempt from the requirements
of this Ordinance:
l. The division or subdivision of land into parcels or tracts of five [5)
acres or more in size which does not involve any new streets or
easements of access;
2. The division of lots or blocks of less than one (1) acre in any
recorded subdivision which does not involve any new stre2ts or
easements of access;
3. The sale or exchange of parcels of iand between owners of adjoining
and contiguous land;
4. The conveyance of parcels of land or interest therein for use as a
right-of-way for railroads or other public utility facilities and
other pipe lines which does not involve any new streets or easements
of access;
5. The conveyance of land owned by a railroad or other public utility
which does not involve any new streets or easements of access;
6. The conveyance of 1 and for highway or other public purposes or grants
or conve1ances relatin·J to the dedication of land for public use or
instruments relating to the vacating of land impr~ssed with a public
use.
13.
7. Conveyances made to correct descriptions in prior conveyances.
8. The sa 1 e or exchange of parcels or tracts of 1 and fol 1 owing the
division into no more than two (2) parts of a particular parcel or
tract of land existing on July 17, 195Y and not involving any new
streets or easements of access; and
9. The sale of a single lot of less than five(5) acres from a larger
tract when a survey is made by a registered surveyor; provided, that
this exemption shall not apply to the sale of any subsequent lots from
the same larger tract of land, as detennined by the dimensions and
configuration of the larger tract on October 1, 1Y73, and provided
also that this exemption does not invalidate any local requirements
applicable to the subdivision of land. (See Chapter 109, Plats Act,
Illinois Revised Statutes.)

SECTION 5.03 - PLANNED DEVELOPMENT REGULATION
All sections of the Itasca Zoning Ordinance which regulate Planned Developments
excluding those sections which pertain solely to zoning regulations, are hereby
incorporated into the Itasca Zoning Ordinance by this section and are of full
force and effect as though set our fully herein.
14.
SECTION 6.00 - GENERAL GUIDELINES
Any owner of land which is within the corporate limits of the Village of Itasca
or within one and one-half (l-1/2) miles of such corporate limits or
unincorporated land, wishing to divide the same into lots or to resuqd~vide for .... ,,,.
the purpose of sale or assessment, or both, or wishing to dedicate streets,
alleys, or other lands for public use, shall follow the procedures and
requirements of this Ordinance.
6.01 - PRELIMINARY CONSULTATION
A. Informal Meeting. The subdivider submits a letter of intent to the
President of the Village Board of Trustees, with a copy of the Plan
Commission requesting an informal meeting with the Plan Commission to
discuss the proposed subdivision and proposed improvements. The
subdivider shall present to the Plan Commission general subdivision
information which shall describe or outline the existing conditions of
the site and the proposed development. The Plan Commission shall
determine the need for a sketch plan review of the proposed
development. If the Plan Commission determines that there is no need
for a sketch plan review, they shall advise the subdivider to proceed
directly to the preliminary plan phase.
B. Sketch Plan Review. When the Plan Commission determines that there is
a need for a sketch plan review of the proposed subdivision, the
subdivider shall prepare ten (lll) copies of the following information
for presentation to the Plan Commission at a regularly scheduled
·meeting:
1. General Subdivision Information
2. Sketch Plan
3. Tentative Enoineering Proposals
See Section 8.02 for details of these elements.
C. Subdivider Advised. The Plan Commission, after checking the proposed
sketch plan, shall advise the subdivider as to the apparent adequacy
of the proposed plan and apprises the subdivider of any requirements
the Village might have that should be incorporated into the design of
the subdivision.
6.02 - PRELIMINARY PLAN
A. Plan and Application. The subdivider prepares a preliminary plan,
including a proposal for the installation of improvements and intended
dedication or reservations of pu~lic lands, and submits an application
and ten (lOj copies of the proposed plan to the Village Clerk.
15.
B. Action by Village Clerk. The Village Clerk refers the preliminary
plan to the Village of Itasca Plan Commission not less that ten (10)
da1s prior to a regularly scheduled meeting of the Plan Commission.
C. Action by Plan Commission. The Plan Commission distributes copies of
the preliminary plan to concerned local, district, and county
officials for their review and comments. The Plan Commission shall
obtain the required written review comments and any recommendations
from the Village Engineer, and concerned public officials within
twenty (20) days. Then, after applying the provisions of the
Ordinance, it either recommends to approve the preliminary plan, or
recommends to approve the preliminary plan subject to modification, or
recommends to reject the preliminary plan. ·Findings a.nd
recommendations are reported to the Village aoard and subdivider.
D. Action by Village Board. The Village Board approves, rejects or
modifies the preliminary plan.
6.03 - FINAL PLAT
A. Plat and Documents. After complying with the above requirements the
subdivider prepares and submits to the Village Clerk, the original and
ten (10) copies of the final plat incorporating all required · ·· ·-- ·
modifications to the preliminary plan.
B. Action by Villaoe Clerk. The Village Clerk refers the final plat to
the Plan Commission not less than ten (10) working days prior to a
reguTarly scheduled meeting of tne Plan Commission.
C. Action by Plan Commission. The Plan Commission determines whether or
not the final plat is in conformance with the approved preliminary
plan and forwards the plat, with its recommendaton, to the Village
Board.
D. Action by Village Board. The Vill~ge Board approves, rejects, or
modifies the final plat.
£. Recording of Plat. After the approval of the final plat, the Village
Clerk records the plat with the Recorder of Deeds of Cook or DuPage
Counties; and the subdivider may then proceed to develop and sell lots
of his subdivision in accordance with this Ordinance.
15.
SECTION 7 .00 - GENERAL PROVISIONS FOR SUBDIVISION APPROVAL
7 .01 - PLAN COMMIS!ON GUIDELINES
A. Particular Attention of the Plan Commission. The Plan Commission, in
the examination of subdivision plans or plats for approval, and in the
application of this Ordinance, shall take into consideration the
requirements of the community and the best use of the land being
-"'--·sub-divided. Particular attention shall be given to width and location
of streets, suitable sanitary utilities, storm water drainage, lot
sizes and arrangements, as well as local requirements such as parks
and playgrounds, schools, and recreation sites, and other public uses.
B. Conformity with Comprehensive Plan. The Plan Commission shall
especially require that all subdivision conform to the provisions and
conditions of the Official Comprehensive Pian, adopted October 17,
1977. Plat approval may be i;ithheld if a subdivision does not conform
to the provisions of the Comprehensive Plan.
C. Area Plan Required. Where a tract of land proposed for a subdivision
is part of a larger, logical subdivision unit in relation to the
Village as a whole, the Plan Commission r,1ay, before recommending
approval, request that the subdivider submit a plan for the entire
area or neighborhood to be used by the Pian Commission as an aid i~
judging the proposed plan. The Village Engineer will make available,
to the subdivider, any Village information that is available
concerning the area for which the plan is to be developed.
D. Storm Water Provisions Required. The Plan Commission shall not
recommend for approval by the Vi11 age Board any plan or pl at of
subdivision which does not make adequate provision for storm or flood
water runoff channels or basins.
E. Preservation of Natural Features. In a11 subdivisions due regard
shall be given to the preservation of natural features such as large
trees, watercourses, historical sites or structures, and similar
features.
F. Solar Lot Access. The design of a subdivision and iti layout may
affect the energy efficiency of the building to be placed upon it and
other factors sucl1 as, impact on privacy, landscaping and, for solar
purposes, a shadJwing of the other person's solar reception.
The Plan Commission ma; consider variations or solar easements to
~rovide for changes in lot configuration in order to provide for
design methods to reduce energy consumption.
17.
Energy conservation methods may include, but not be limited to,
natural ventilation of structures, siting of structures in relation to
prevailing breezes and sun angles, insulation of structures, use of
landscape material for shade, direction of breezes, and transpiration.
7.02 - UNSUITABLE LAND
No land shall be subdivided for any use which is determined by the Pian
Commission, after investigation by the Village Engineer, to be unsuitable
for such use by reason of flooding or bad drainage, adverse earth or rock
formation or topography, or any other feature likely to be harmf"l to
health, safety, or welfare of the future residents in the proposed
subdivision or of the community. Land located outside areas of special
flood hazard may be subdivided only in the subdivider agrees to making
improvements which will, in the opinion of the Village Engineer, make the
area safe for occupancy and provide adequate lot and street drainage and
storm water detention facilities, the subdivision may then be approved.
7.03 - AREAS OF SPECIAL FLOOD HAZARD
When land is determined to be unsuitable b; reason of flooding or wetlands,
refer to the Municipal Code, and the Standards and Specifications for
Required Land Improvements.
:r
7.04 - STORMWATER M~NAGEMENT
The purpose of this Section is to provide standards and regulations governing
land development in order to reduce or prevent flooding and at the same time
r"nimize damage to real property, protecting the public health, safety, and
welfare. {Refer to the Municipal Code.)
7.05 - DEDICATION OF LAND FOR ?UBL!C USE
A. Acceptance of Designated land. When a final plat of a subdivision has
been approved by the Village aoard and all other required approvals
are obtained and the plat is recorded, the approval shall constitute
acceptance for the purpose designated on the plat of all lands shown
on the plat as dedicated to the public, excepting street dedications
which shall be accepted only after inspection and recommendation by
the Village Engineer.
B. Refusal of Designated Land. Whenever a preliminary plan includes a
proposed dedication of land to public use and the Plan Commission
finds that such land is not required or not suitable for public use,
the Plan Commission may either refuse to approve such dedication or
require the rearrangement of lots in the proposed subdivision to
include such land.
13.
C. Minimum Dedication. For minimum dedication of land for public use
exclusive of public dedicated roads refer to Section 7.07 of this
Ordinance.
7.0b - RESERVATION OF PUBLIC SPACES AND SITES
A. Plan to Show Public Land. Whenever a tract to be subdivided includes
a proposed site for a park, playground, school, or other public use as
indicated on the Official Map of the Village of Itasca, such space
shall be suitabl; incorporated by the developer into his subdivision
plat after proper determination of its necessity by the Plan
Commission and the appropriate Village office or other public agency
involved in the development of such public open space.
B. Adeauate Open Space Required.
1. Flood Plain Areas. The Village Board may, when It deems it
necessary for the health, safety, or welfare of the present and
future population of the area and necessary to the conservation
of water, drainage, and sanitary facilities, prohibit subdivision
of any portion of the property which lies within the flood plain
or ant stream or drainage course. These flood plain areas shall
be preserved from any and all destruction or damage resulting
from clearing, grading, or dumping. of earth, waste material, or .... ~ •.
stumps. (Refer to the Standards and Specifications for Required
land Improvements.)
2. Park and Playground Sites. Refer to Itasca Park District.
C. · Acquisition of Land for Public Use. The Plan Commission shall
consider all preliminary plans and adopted or proposed studies related
thereto to determine the need for acquisition for public use of any of
the land included in the preliminary plan. Land may be acquired for:
parks, playgrounds, or other public recreation areas, or other public
purposes as provided by law.
l. Referral to Public Body. The Pl an Commission shal 1 refer the
plan to the public body concerned with acquisition for its
consideration and report. The Pian Commission maj propose
alternate areas for such acquisition and shall allow the public
body or agency thirty (30) days for reply. The agencj'S
recommendation, if affirmative, shall include a map showing the
boundaries and area of the parcel to be acquired and an estimate
of the time required to complete the acquisition.
2. Notice to Property Owner. Upon receipt of an affirmative report
from an acquiring agency the Plan Commission shall notify the
property owner and shall desi~nate on the preliminary plan and
final plat that area proposed to be acquired by the public boc'y.
l~.
3. Duration of Land Reservation. The acquisition of land reserved
by a public agency on the preliminary plan or final plat shall be
Initiated within twelve (12) months of notification, in writing,
from the owner that he intends to develop the land.
Such letter of intent shall be accompanied by a sketch plan for
the proposed development and a tentative schedule of
construction. Failure on the part of the public agency to
initiate acquisition within the prescribed twelve (12) months
shd 11 res ult In the remova 1 of the "reserved" designation from
the property involved and the freeing of the property for private
development.
7 .07 - DEDICATION OF PAKK AND SCHOOL SITES OR FuR PAYMENTS OR FEES IN-LIEU-OF
As a condition of approval of the Final Plat of Subdivision or a Planned
Development, each subdivider shall be required to dedicata land for park
and recreational purposes and for school sites to serve the immediate and
future needs of the residents of the development, or to provide a cash
contribution in-lieu-of actual land dedication, or a combination of both,
at the option of the Vfllage Board in accordance with the fol lowing
criteria and formula:
A. Criteria for Requiring Park and Recreation Land Dedication:
1. Requirements and Population Ratio .. The ultimate densi~y of
proposed development shall relate directly to the amount of land
required for dedication. The total requirement shall be five and
one-half (5.5) acres of land per one thousand (1,000) of ultimate
population in accordance with the following classifications:

2. Location. The Official Comprehensive Plan or the Itasca Park District
. Plan shall be used as guidelines in locating sites. A park site
adjoining all elementary school sites of not less than five (Si acres
shall be considered a minimum. A central location which will equally
serve the entire development is most desirable. In large developments
these sites can be located throughout the development according to
established standards for park area distances.
3. Credit for Private Open Spaces and Recreation Areas. When subdividers
.or developers provide their own open space for recreation areas and
facilities, it has the effect of reducing the demand for local public
recreation services. Depending on the size of the development, a
portion of the park and recreation area in subdivisions or planned
developments may at the option of the Village Board be prnided in the
form of "private" open spac2 in-lieu-of dedicated "public" open
space. The extent of the same shall be determined by the Village
Board, based upon the needs of the projected residents and in
confonnance to the total park and recreation land requirements for the
general area.
In general, a substitution of private open space for dedicated parks will
imply a substantially higher degree of improvement and the installation of
recreational facilities and equipment by the developer as part of his
obligation. Detailed plans of such areas, including specifications of
facilities to be installed, shall be approved bJ the Village; and before
any credit is given for private recreation areas, the subdivider or
deve1oper shall guarantee that these private recreation areas will be
permanently maintained for such use by the execution of the appropriate
legal documents. Private "swimming clubs" are included in this provision.
When an adjustment for private recreation areas is warranted it will be
necessary to compute the total parkland dedication that would have been
required from the subdivision or Planned Development and then su~tract the
credit to be given.
B. Criteria for Requiring School Site Dedication:
l. Requirement and Population Ratio. The ultimate number of
students to be generated by a subdivision or planned development
shall relate directly to the amount of land required to be
dedicated for school sites. The land dedication requirement
shall be determined by obtaining the ratio of: (1) estimated
children to be served in each such school classification over the
two (2j maximum recommended number of students to be served in
each such school c1assific3tion as stated herein and the applying
such ratio to the (3) said minimum recommended number of acres
for a school site of each such school classification.
The product thereof shal 1 be the acres of 1 and di:emed needed to
have a sufficient· land for school sites to serve the estimated
increased children in each such school classification.
21.
2. School Classification and Size of School Site. Classification and
size of school sites within the Village shall be detennined in
accordance with the following criteria:

3. Location. The Comprehensive Plan and the standards adopted b; the
affected school district shall be used as a guideline in locating
sit es.
C. Criteria for Requiring a Contribution Jn-Lieu-Of Park and School
Sites. Where tile development is small and the resulting site is too
small to be practical or when the available land is inappropriate for
park purposes of a school site, the Village Board shall require the
subdivider or developer to pay a cash contribution in-lieu-of land
dedication required.
The cash contributions in-lieu-of park and recreation land dedica~ion
shall be held in trYst by the Village or other public body designated
by the Village, solely for the acquisition of park and recreation land
as herein before classified which will be available to serve the
immediate or future needs of the residents of that subdivision or
development or for the improvement of other existing local park and
recreation land which already serves such needs. The cash
contribution in-lieu-of school sites shall be held in trust by the
Village, or other public body desi3nated by the Village, solely for
use in the acquisition of land for a school site, for improvement of a
school site or for construction or improvement of a school building to
serve the immediate or future needs of children from that subdivision
or development.
1. Fair Market Value. The cash contribution in-lieu-of land shall
be based on the "fair market value" of the acres of land in the
area improved as specified h~rein, that otherwise would have been
dedicated as park and recreation and school sites. The
subdivider or developer shall submit an appraisal showing the
"fair market value• of such improved land in the area of his
development or other evidence thereof. The final determination
of said "fair market value" per acre of such improved land shall
be made by the Village Board based upon such information
submitted by the subdivider or developer and from other sources
which may be submitted to the Village Board by the park district,
school district, or others.
22.
2. Criteria for Requiring Dedication and a Fee.
There will be situations in subdivisions or planned developments
when a combination of land dedication and a contribution.
in-lieu-of land are both necessary. These occaisions ~iJl arise
when:
a. Only a portion of the land to be developed is proposed as
the location for a park or school site. That portion of the
land within the subdivision falling within the park or school
location shall be a dedicated site as required by this
Section, and a cash contribution in-lieu-of-thereof shall be
required for any additional land that woJld have to be
dedicated.
b. A major part of the local park or recreation site or school
site has already been acquired and only a sma11 portion of
land is needed from the development to complete the site.
The remaining portions shall be required by dedication, and
a cash contribution in-lieu-of-thereof shall be required.
D. Densitz Formula. ihe most recent Table of Estimated Ultimate
Population Density in the Appendix shall be considered indicative of
current and short-range projected trends in family size for new
construction and shall be used in calculating the amount of required
dedicated acres or the cash contributio~ in-lieu-of unless a written
objection is filed thereto by the subdivider or developer.
In the event a subdivider or developer or affected public body files a
written objection to the Table of Estimated Ultimate Population
contained in the Appendix, he shall submit his own demographic study
showing the estimated additional population to be generated from the
subdivision or Planned Development and in that event, final
detennination of the density formula to be used in such calculations
shall be made bi the Village Board based upon such d~nographic
information submitted by the subdivider or developer and from other·
sources which may be submitted to the Village Board bi the park
districts, school districts, or others. Population density, age
distribution and local conditions change over the years, and the
specific formula for the dedication of land, or the payment of fees
in-lieu-of-thereto as stated herein, is subject to periodic review and
amendment if necessary.

body calls for a iarger amount of park and recreational land or school

assemble usable recreation areas or school sites without hardship on a

locations of the dedicated site as well as its surroundings shal~ be
suitable for its intended purposes and consistent with the standards
adopted by the affected public body. Grading on sites dedicated for
park and recreational uses and for school sites shall not differ
greatly from surrounding land.
Improved Sites. All sites dedicated for any purpose under this
Section, shall be dedicated in a condition ready for full service of
electrical, water, sewer, and streets (including enclosed draina;e,
curb and gutter, sidewalk and trees) as applicable to the location of
the site, as acceptable provision made therefor.
DEDICATION AND DEVELOPMENT OF DETENTION PONDS OR FUNDS IN-LIEU-THEREOF
Contribution and Development of Detention Ponds or Funds Reouired. No
final plat shall be approved until such time as the subdivider shall
have f:illy complied with the provisions of this Ordinance by either
submitting detailed plans and specifications for the development of
storm water detention ponds (as required by the development of his
subdivisioni to be constructed off the site in an area desi9nated by
the Vil lase of Itasca in accordance with Section C., below.
24.
B. Engineering Studies. The developer, at his expense, shall hire a
professional engineer, registered in the State of Illinois, to prepare
a detailed study of the detention required by the subdivision.
C. Location of Detention Ponds. After the required storm water ·detention
has been determineo as specified in paragraph "A", these calculations
shall be submitted to the Vi11age for review and recommendation by the
Village Engineer.
If the detention area required to serve the proposed subdivision is
more than three (3) acre feet in size, the detention pond shall be
constructed as part of the subdivision improvements.
In subdivisions where less than three (3) acre feet of detention is
required, the developer may deposit with the Village of Itasca,
in-lieu-of construction of detention area, the funds necessary to
provide for construction of the required detention facilities of the
site and as designated by the Village of Itasca.
D. Determination of the Cost of Off-Site Detention Ponds. If it has been
determined {by the criteria specified in paragraph "C" above) that the
detention pond is to be constructed off the site of the subdivision,
the developer, at his expense, shall have a professional engineer,
.registered in the State of Illinois, prepare an estimate of the cost
to construct the detention pond at the designated site, including the
comparable cost of the land. The estimate shall be submitted to the
Village for review by the Village Engineer.
Upon approval by the Village, the funds in the amount of the approved
estimate and a cashier's check shall be deposited with the Village of
Itasca in-lieu-of the construction of the detention pond on the site.
Once deposited with the Village, the funds shall become the property
of the Village of Itasca for the sole use of construction and
.Tiaintenance of storm water management facilities.
7.09 - PLATS OF SUBDIVISION
A. Vacation of a Plat of Subdivision. Any plat or any part of a plat may
be vacated by the owner of the premises, at any time before the sale
of any lot therein, by a written instrument, to which a copy of such
plat shall be attached declaring the same to be vacated.
B. Preliminary Consultation Required. Prior to the submission of the
certified Plat of Survey required herein, the subdivider shall meet
with the Village Engineer prior to meeting with the Plan Commission
for the purpose of minimizing the risk of objections to, or rejection
of, the prepared Plat of Survey, and for.the purpose of ascertaining
the problems and requirements affecting his property.
25.
/
C. Procedure for Approval. The owner or subdivider shall file with the
Village Clerk, the original and four (4) contact prints of a certified
plat of survey showing the proposed division of such lots, block,
parcels, or tracts of land. The ori~inal and ten (1) prints of the
Plat of Survey shall be forwarded to the Plan Commission not· less that
fifteen {15) working days before the meeting of the next Plan
Commission. Within forty {40j days after the meeting at which the
Plat of Survey is referred to the Plan Commission, the Village
Engineer shall notify the owner or subdivider whether a new street or
easement of access is required. In the event that a new street or
easement of access is required, the notice shall stipulate that an
application for final plat approval containing such maps,
certifications, and supporting documents as required by the Plan
Commission shall be filed with the Village Clerk for processing as
herein set forth in this Ordinance.
The Plan Commission shall, within forty-five (45) days, recommend to
approve, approve conditionally, or reject the proposal. The Vi1lage
Board shall be notified in writing of any conditions of approval or
the reasons for rejection.
0. Re5uirements for Approval
l. Compliance with this Ordinance .. To the extent that it is
reasonable, the division of land shall comply with the provisions
of this. Ordinance governing general requirements, desi~n
standards, and required improvements.
2. Survey. The survey shall be performed and the plat prepared by a
Registered Illinois Land Surveyor.
3. Monuments. All corners shall be monumented as follows:
a. All lot corners shall be monumented in the field by iron
pipes at least twenty-four (24) inches long and one (1) inch
in diameter, or by round or square iron bars at least
t'llenty-four (24) inches long.
b. The lines of lots that extend to rivers or streams shall be
monumented in the field by iron pipes at least thirty (3j
inches long and one (l) inch in diameter or by round or
square iron bars at least thirty (30i inches long. These
monuments shall be placed at the point of intersection of
the river or stream lot line with a meander line established
not less that twenty (20) feet back from the bank of the
river or stream.
26.
E. Certificates and Affidavits.
1. Affidavits Required. The survey plat shall include the affidavit
of the surveyor who surveyed and mapped the parcel, typed,
lettered, or reproduced legibly with non-fading black ink, giving
a clear and concise description of the land surveyed by bearings
and distances, commencing with some corner marked and established
in the U.S. Public Land Survey or some corner providing reference
to a corner marked and established In the U.S. Public Land
Survey. Such affidavit shall include the statement of the
surveyor to the effect that they have fully complied with the
requirements of this section.
2. Certificates Required. The certificate of approval of the Plan
Commission shall be typed, lettered, or reproduced legibly with
non-fading black ink on the face of the original survey plat.
F. Filing of Surve1 Plat. The Village Clerk shall retain a copy of the
approved survey map and any supporting documents as required by the
Plan Commission for the Village records. The Village Clerk shall also
record the original of the approved survey plat with the Recorder of
Deeds of Cook or DuPage Counties.
27.
SECTION B.00 - PROCEDURE FOR SUBDiVISION APPROVAL
tl.01 PRELIMINARY CONSULTATION
Prior to the submission of the preliminary plan of any proposed subdivision
within the jurisdiction of this Ordinance, the subdivider shall make known any
intentions to the Plan Commission. During this preliminary or pre-application
stage, the following actions shall be taken:
A. Action by the Subdivider. The subdivider shall meet with the Plan
Commission for the purpose of presenting a general outline of a
proposal, including but not necessarily limited to the following:
1. Written Notification. Written notification in the form of a
letter of intent from the sudivlder to the Plan Commission
establishing the subdivider's intent to develop the land.
2. General Subdivision Information. General subdivision information
that shall describe or outline the existing conditions of this
site and the proposed development. This information shall
include data on existing covenants, land characteristics, and
available community facilities and utilities. Information
describing the subdivision proposal shall include the number of
residential lots and units broken down bj type, square foota~e of
building, and bedroom count; typical lot width and depth;
business areas; schools, playgrounds and park areas; other public
areas; traffic study; proposed protective covenants and proposed
utilities; street improvements; and soil boring test results.
B. Action b; the Plan Commission. The Plan Commission shall discuss the
proposed subdivision with the subdivider and so advise of any Village
plans or projects which might affect the proposed subdivision, the
procedural steps, design and improvement standards, and the general
planning requirements. The Plan Commission shall determine the need
for a sketch plan review of the proposed development. If the Plan
Commission determines that there is no need for a sketch plan review,
they shall advise the subdivider to proceed directly to the
preliminary plan phase as described in Section d.02. If the Plan
Commission determines that there is a need for a sketch plan review,
thej shall then inform the subdivider that a review of the sketch plan
is needed at a regularly scheduled meeting.
C. Action b; the Subdivider. The subdivider shall prov1ae the Plan
Commission with ten (10) copies of the general subdivision information
described in A-2 above. The Subdivider shall also prepare ten (lOj
copies of the following information for presentation to the Plan
Commission.
2(j.
l. Sketch Plan. A plan prepared on reproducible medium that shall
show in simple sketch form the proposed layout of streets, lots'
and other features in relation to existing conditions. The
sketch plan may be a free hand sketch made directly on.a. print of
the topographic surve1. The sketch plan shall include the
existin9 topographic data and contours of not more than five (S}
foot intervals. This ma1 be attached to U.S.G.S. topographic
data.
2. Tentative En3ineering Proposals.
regarding water supply, sewerage
and street improvements.
Tentative en~ineering proposals
disposal, stormwater drainage,
D. Action by the Plan Commission. The Plan Commission in conjunction
with the Village Engineer shall review the general subdivision
information, sketch plan, and tentative engineering proposals and
proceed with the following investigations:
l. Zoning Check. Check the existing zonin9 of the tract and advise
the subdivider if a zoning change Is necessary or desirable.
2. Public Facility Impact. Detennine the adequacy of existin9 or
proposed schools, parks, and other public spaces in the vicinity
of the proposed subdivision in orchestration with authorized
taxing bodies involved.
3. Site Inspection. Inspect the site or otherwise determine its
relationship to major streets, utility systems, and adjacent land
uses, and determine an; unusual problems in re;ard to topography,
uti'lities, flooding, etc.
4. School Sites. Advise the developer of the potential acreage
allotment, or funds in-lieu-thereof, to be donated and utilized
for public school sites based upon the developer's estimates of
the number and type of dwelling units to be constructed, the
potent I al needs of each affected school district, and the
Comprehensive Plan or Official Map of the Village of Itasca.
Refer to Section 7.07 of this Ordinance.
5. Comprehensive Plan Conformity. Advise the developer of the
Comprehensive Plan which delineates the land use areas.
b. Location of Flood Plains and Wetlands. Advise the developer of
the need for a Special Use hearing if the proposed subdivisioi is
located on a flood plain or wetland area as identified in
Ordinance No. 474-77 as amended.
2~.
7. Subdivider Advised. The Plan Commission, after checking the
proposed sketch ~lan, shall advise the subdivider no later than
the next regulorly scheduled meeting following the presentation
of the sketch plan as to the apparent adequacy of the proposed
plan and apprises the subdivider of any requirements the Village
might have that should be incorporated into the design of the
subdivision.

8. 03 - PRELIMINARY PLAN REQUIREMENTS
The purpose of the preliminary plan is to allow the Plan Commission and other
public bodies to determine whether the proposed layout of the land in .question
is satisfactory from the standpoint of the public interest. The preliminary
plan shall be prepared by a qualified professional trained and experienced in
the layout of subdivisions.
The following graphic and descriptive items are normally required to be shown
on the preliminary plan and the accompanying application for approval. The
lack of information under any item specified herein, or improper information
supplied by the applicant, shall be a cause for disapproval of a preliminary
pl an.
A. Application for Approval. Written application oy the owner, or his
agent, for approval, on forms furnished by the Plan Commission, shall
accompany each preliminary plan and contain the following information:
1. Name for File Identification
a. Name of subdivision if property is within an existing
subdivision.
b. Proposed name if not within a previously platted
subdivision. The proposed name shall not duplicate the name
of any plat previously recorded.in Cook or Du Page Counties.
c. Name of property if no subdivision name has been chosen.
(This is commonly the name by which the property is locally
known.)
2. Location and Description of Property. Location of property by.
government lot, section, township, range, and county.
3. Basic Facts and Proposals Pertaining to the Property.
a. Size of tract in acres or of existing lots, if any, in
square feet.
b. Existing zonin~ classification of property and any propcsed
rezoning to be requested.
c. Number of iots proposed in subdivision.
d. Area of lots proposed; minimum, average, and maximum.
e. Proposed linka~e with water and sewer facilities.
f. Any other proposals, such as parcels of land intended tc be
dedicated, conveyed, or reserved for public use, and the
conditions proposed for such disposal and use.
33.
4. Information as to Ownership, Preparation of Plan, and Submission.
a. Name and address, including telephone number, of legal owner
or agent of property and citation of last instrument
conveying title to each parcel of property involved in the
proposed subdivision, giving grantor, grantee, date, and
land records reference.
b. Citation of an; existing legal rights-of-way or easements
affecting the property.
c. Existing covenants on the property, if any.
d. Name and address, including telephone number, of the
professional\si responsible for the subdivision design shall
be shown on the preliminary plan as submitted by a
Registered Professional engineer of Illinois, responsible
for the design of public improvements, and Registered
Illinois Land Surveyor, responsible for surveys.
B. School Demographic Study and Determination of Acreage Allotment
:.e:
l. Demo graphic Study Requirements. A school demo ;ra phi c study sha 11
be prepared by the subdivider and shall be subnitted for approval
in conjunction with the preli~inary plan. It shall include, but
need not be limited to the following:
a. The number and types of dwelling units to be constructed
upon approval of the plat, the density of such dwelling

unit by the number of bedro_oms.

approved by and on file with the Village of Itasca. (See
Appendix - Estimated Ultimate Population per Dwelling Unit
Table).
c. Estimates of the number of children to be generated in each

wholly or partially within the dred depicted in any such
pl an.

~enerated from the particular subdivision. Such estimate shall

d. 05 - PROCEDURE FOR APPROVAL OF FINAL PLAT
A. Action by the Subdivider
1. Application to Village Clerk. Application for approval of the
final plat including all engineering drawings, shall be submitted
in writin~ to the Village Clerk and shall be accompanied by the
recording fee and engineering review fees as required in these
regulations. The application shall include the ori~inal and ten
(10) copies of the final plat and all other required documents.
2. Conformance with Preliminary Plan. The final plat sha11 conform
substantially to the preliminary plan as approved, and, if
desired by the Plan Commission, it shall constitute only that
portion of the approved preliminary plan which the subdivider
proposes to record and develop at the time; provided, however,
that such portion conforms to all requirements of these
regulations. Any extension of time for the remaining portion of
the preliminary plan is subject to the discretion of the Plan
Commission.
B. Action by the Village Clerk. The Village Clerk shall submit the final
plat and other required documents to the Plan Commission far its
review and recommendations for approval or disapproval at least ten
(10) days prior to a regularly scheduled meeting.
C. Action by the Plan Commission. Within two (2i months after its
regularly scheduled meeting, at which the application for approval of
final plat is reviewed, the Plan Commission shall approve or
disapprove it. If the Plan Commission approves, it shall affix upon
ti1e plat, the certifying si9nature of its Chairperson. If it
disapproves, it shall set forth its reasons in its own records and
provide the applicant and the Village Board with a copy.
D. Action by the Villaoe Board.
1. Plat Submitted to the Village Board. After approval of tile final
plat by the Plan Commission and the fulfillment of the
requir1ments of these re9ulations, one (1) tracing of the final
plat of the subdivision, drawn in ink on reproducible drafting
material not to exceed thirty-six inch~s by forty-eight inches
(36" x 48") in size, shall be submitted to the Village aoard for
approval.
2. Action by the Village Board. Action raa; be taken by tne Vil lase
Board within two (2) months after the meeting at which the final
plat, engineering specifications for required land improvements,
and all other drawings, maps and other required documents ha1e
been submitted for its approval. The applicant and the Vil1<3e
Board may mutually agree to extend the two (2) month period.
45.
3. Approved Plat Copies. Upon approval by the Village Board,
Village Clerk shall receive from the subdivider one (1) mylar
reproducible print and three (3j contact prints of the approved
final plat, and three (3) copies of the approved supporting
documents. The cost of such prints and copies of such documents
shall be paid by the subdivider.
a. One {l) contact print of the final plat, when applicable,
one (1) cop/ of the accompanying protective covenants, and
one (li copy of the supporting dociJments shall be delivered
to the Plan Commission;
b. One (lj contact print and all specifications, drawings, and
estimates shall be delivered to the Village Engineer; and
c. One (1) transparency print and one (li contact print and all
other supporting documents shall be retained by the Village
Cl erk.
E. Filing of Final Plat
1. Filing with County. Upon approval by the Village Board, Village
Clerk shall record the plat with the Cook or Du Page County
Recorder within two (2) months. · ·
2. Filing for Local Record. The final plat in exact form as
approved by the Village Board, and as filed with the Cook or Du
Page County Recorder, shall be filed for local record by the
Village Clerk. Such local file copy shall bear the appropriate
documentation number such as assigned by the Cook or DuPage
County Recorder.
F. Orawings and Date for Final Approval. The final plat shall be
accurately drawn in ink on reproducible drafting material, in a manner
that's clear and legible so that transparent or contact prints or
photostatic copies can be made. The final plat shall be at a scale of
fifty (50) feet to the inch when the longest dimension of the tract is
seven hundred (700) feet or less, and one hundred (100) feet to the
inch when the longest dimension of the tract is more than seven
hundred (700) feet, at no time shall the scale be other than twenty
{~O), ten (10), five (5), or one (1) foot to the inch be used. Where
necessary, the plat may be drawn on several sheets accompanied by an
index sheet showing the entire subdivision. For large subdivisions,
the final plat may be submitted for approval progressivel/ in
contiguous sections satisfactory to the Plan Commission.

ways, and utility easements.

_dedicated for schools, parks, playgrounds, or other public uses,
or for the exclusive use of property owners within the
subdivision. Such areas shall be designated by letter or number
·and by legal description.
5. Accurate Dimensions. Accurate angular and lineal dimensions for
all lines, angles, radii, and arcs used to des.cribe all
boundaries including perimeter surv~y of tract, streets,
easements, areas to be reserved or dedicated for public use, and
other important features. Error of closure of boundary line
surveys shall not exceed one in ten thousand (one (1) foot for
each ten thousand (10,000j feet of perimeter survey). Angular
error shall not exceed plus or minus twenty (20) seconds. Lot
lines shall show dimensions in feet and hundreths, and when an
angle occurs in any 1 ot 1 ine between 1 ot corners, the measurE·ment
of the angle shall be shown in degrees, minutes, and seconds.
The final plat shall show accurately the location of all
permanent lot markers as actually installed.
6. Control Points. True angles and distances to the nearest
established street lines and official monuments (not less than
three (3), which shall be accurately described in the plat by
location, size, and elevation, to which all dimensions, anglfs,
bearings, and similar data on the plat shal 1 be referred.
7. Identification System. An identification system for all bl or ks
and lJts using consecutive numbers for lots within a block a~i,
where applicable, a street address number in accord with curr~nt
Village policies.

8.07 - CONSTRUCTION OF REQUIRED LAND IMPROVEMENTS
A. Installation Required. The subdivider shall, before the recording of
his final plat, enter into a contract with the Vi11age of Itasca
agreeing to install street and utility improvements and other
improvements indicated on the approved preliminary plan and as
approved in the final engineering documents in accordance with
specifications hereinafter provided. Such contract shall be in such
form as required by Section 8.08 of this Ordinance.
B. Deeding of Improvements. All underground public improvements up ta
the property line shall be deeded over to the Vil lag~ of Itasca and
become the property of the Village after approval by the Village
Engineer and when accepted by resolution of the Village of Itasca.
All labor and material for installing under9round public improvements
shall be furnished by the subdivider. All testing required for
acceptance shall be done by the subdivider under the supervision of
the Village Engineer.
8.0tl - AGREEMENTS AND GUARANTEE OF IMPROVEMENTS
The requirements of this Section shall be complied with prior to the
approval and recording of a Final Plat of Subdivision.
A. Action by the Subdivider. Prior to the filing of an application
for a final plat, the subdivider shall submit the following to
the Village Clerk.
1. Statement of Acreement. A statement of agr~ement that:
a. The land improvements, required by this Ordinance,
shall be completed by the owner or subdivider in
accordance with the plans and specifications approved
by the Village Engineer.
b. Four (4) sets plus one (1) reproducible set on mylar of
as built plans, as required by Section 8.09 shal 1 be
submitted by the owner or subdivider.

be of an amount equal to at least ten (10) percent of the total cost
of the improvements to be accepted.

SECTION Y.00 - PLANNING STANOARDS FOR SUBDIVISION DESIGN
The subdivision of land - including the arrangement, character, extent width,
grade, and location of all streets, cross-walks, easements, sites for parks,
playgrounds, and schools or other land to be dedicated for public use - shall
conform to the Official Comprehensive Plan, (adopted October l~, 1Y77j, and
Official Map of the Village of Itasca. Approval of design standards shall be
considered on the basis of their relation to existing and platted streets,
reasonable circulation of traffic within the subdivision and adjacent land,
topographic conditions, runoff of stormwater, public convenience and safety,
and appropriate relation to the proposed uses of the area to be served.
9.Ul - STREET STANDARDS
A. Street Arran ement. Where such is not shown on the Comprehensive
Plan, adopted October 18, 1977), and/or official Map, the arrangement
of streets within a subdivision shall either:
1. Continuity. Provide for the continuation or projection of
existing principal street in adjacent areas; or
2. Conformity with Plan. Conform to a plan for the area of
neighborhood approved Gr adopted by the Plan Commission to meet a
particular situation where topo~raphical or other conditions make
con ti nuance or conformance to existing streets impracticable.
B. Street Design. All required street rights-of-way, pavement widths,
curves, gradients and sight distances shall be as shown in the
accompanying Standards and Specifications for Required Land
Improvements and in accordance with the following:
1. Street Jogs. Street jogs between residential streets, arterials
and collector streets with ~enterline offsets of less than two
hundred and twenty-five \2251 feet shall be avoided. Street jogs
between minor streets with centerline offsets of less than one
hundred and fifty \i5Di feet shall be avoided. (Se.:
Illustrations).
2. Intersections. It shall be evidenced that all street
intersections and confluences encourage safe and efficient
traffic flow, and, in general, be at or near right angles; c:r1d in
no case shall a street intersect any other street at less than
sixty \60; oe;rees. An intersection of more than two (2j st~eets
shall not be permi•ted.
67.
I
3. Cul-de-Sac Street. A cul-de-sac street, in single family
residential districts shall be not more than five hundred (500)
feet in length, measured from the centerline of the intersecting
street t~ the center of the turnaround. In multiple family
residential areas, cul-de-sac streets shall not be pennitted.
Each cul-de-sac street shall have a terminus of nearly circular
shape with a minimum right-of-way diameter of not less that one
hundred and twenty (120) feet and a pavement outside diameter of
not less that eighty (80i feet.
4. Median Strips. Median strips other than a raised center curb
separating lanes of traffic within a single right-of-way shall
not be allowed. However, where a parkway exists on a new street
which is an extension of the existing street, a median strip may
be constructed not more than five hundred (500) fe:t in length to
provide the transistion to no median strip. All such median
strips as described above shall have barrier curbs with gutters.
5. Access from Arterial Streets. Provisions shall be made for
vehicular and pedestrian access to residential property abutting
an arterial street either by providing: (a) a marginal access
street, or {b) by backing lots to the thoroughfare and ~roviding
access by a collector, minor, or cul-de-sac street one (1) lot
depth removed and with a no-access strip easement not less than
twelve (12j feet wide along the rear lot line. These standards
are established for the purpose of providing protection for the
residential properties and to provide for traffic safety and the
efficient use of the major street for its intended function of
accommodating through traffic.
6. Reserve Strips. Reserve strips or areas enabling access to
"interior lots from public streets are prohibited in residential
subdivisions containing lots less than one (1) acre in area
providing there is no conflict with the applicable zoning
classification. If in the decision of the Plan Commission all
purposes of this Ordinance are served, a variance of up to ten
(10) percent in area may be granted each resulting lot providing
the total being divided shall not be contructed to be less than
two (2j acres in area. Reserve strips shall not be allowed on
private streets.

l. Planned Developments

possible therewith. Pavement shall be of concrete except in

and similar structures approved by Village Engineer prior or

Commission now or hereafter effective, and the owner or subdivider of
any property to be served from such underground installations shall be
responsible for compliance with the rules and re~ulations applicable
to such underground facilities, now and hereafter effective and filed
with said Commission pursuant to the Illinois Public Utilities Act, of
any public utility whose services are required to be provided by such
underground facilities.

of any two (2j ri9ht-of-wa1 lines. (See Illustrationsj.

D. Easement Responsibility. Each lot owner shall be responsible for the
maintenance, operation, and preservation of all drainage structures,
both on the surface and underground, which cross or enter upon his lot
. or lots. The owner may relocate, within the bounds of his lot or
lots, and draina3e structure subject to prior approval by the Village,
Engineer, however, he must preserve the hydraulic characteristics of
such structures.
9.03. - BLOCKS
A. Configuration of Blocks. The shape of blocks shall be determined by
topographical features, the basic street system and the traffic
pattern, lot depths, and areas designated for public and other
non-residential land uses. In addition to these, the lengths, widths,
and shapes of blocks sha 11 be determined with due regard to:
l. Site Adeouacy. Provision of adequate building sites suitable to
the special needs of the type of use contemplated.
2. Zoning. Zoning requirements as to lot sizes and dimensions
within the corporate limits of the Village of Itasca.
3. Convenience. Needs for convenient access, circulation, control
and safety of street traffic.
B. Length of Blocks
l. Residential. In residential subdivisions, the maximum length of
blocks containing lots of seventy-five (75) feet and over in
width shall be eighteen hundred (1800) feet, and the maximum
length of blocks containing lots less than seventy-five (75) feet
in width shall be twelve hundred (1200) lineal feet. No block
sha11 be less than nine hundred (900i linea1 feet in length
unless recommended by the Plan Commission and approved by the
Village Board.
2. Non-Residential. In other than residential subdivisions, maximilm
length of blocks sha11 be as recommended by the Vi11 age En~ineer
and approved by the Village Board.
C. Non-Residentail Blocks. Blocks or portions thereof intended for
non-residentia1 use shall be designated as such, and the plan shall
show adequate off-street areas to provide for parking, loading drcks,
and other such facilities in accordance with the Itasca Zoning
Ordinance.
73.
I
'
0. Subdivision Bordering Public Rights-of-Way. Where a subdivision
borders on or contains a rail.road right-of-way or limited access
thoroughfare right-of-way, the Plan Commission may require a street
approximately parallel to and on each side of such right-of-way at a
distance suitable for the appropriate use of the intervening land as
for: {a) park purposes, (b) deep residential lots backing to
railroad or primary street with planting screen in a non-access area
at rear of property lines of lots, or (c) motor vehicle parking,
business, or industry in appropriate districts. Such distances shall
be determined with due regard for the requirements of approach grades
and future grade separations.
9.04 - LOTS
A. Configuration of Lots. The lot size, width, depth, sha?e, and
orientation shall be appropriate for the location of the subdivision
and for the type of development and use contemplated and, in general,
lots should be as nearly rectangular in shape as parcticable.
1. Conformance with 2oning Regulations. Width and area of lots
shall c"nform with lot width and area requirements set forth in
the 2oning Ordinance of the Village of Itasca or that of Cook or
Du Page Counties in the unincorporated areas beyond the village
1 imits.
In case of corner lots, the Plan Commiss.ion may make variations
to enco~rage the proper development of intersection design and
traffic safety; and corner lots shall be increased in width by
twenty-five (25) percent over the width of typical interior lot
except where the typical lot is ninety (90) feet wide or more.
2. Non-Residential Lots. Width, area, and depth of lots in a
non-residential subdivision shall be as specified in the Itasca
Zoning Ordinance.
3. Side Lot Lines. Side lot lines of lots shall be at right an"les
or radial to the street line, or substantially so.
4. Butt Lots. Butt lots shall be platted at least five (5) feet
wider than the average interior lots in developments containing·
lots less than twelve thousand (12,000) square feet in area.
B. Access to Lots. All lots shall abut on a publicly dedicated street.
74.
.•. --·
C. Separation for Major Streets. Double frontage and reverse frontage
lots shall be avoided except where essential to provide separation of
residential development from major streets or highways or to overcome
specific disadvantages of topography, orientation and noise:
An easement shall be provided, the width of which shall be determined
by the Village Engineer, (but in on case less than twelve (12) feet
widej for the purpose of providing a noise and si;ht barrier and to
prevent the right of access across the rear or side lot line of lots
abutting such highway and/or major thoroughfare. Within this easement
shall be constructed or installed an earth berm, landscape planting,
or a fence which is to be continuous. The Village Engineer shall
det2rmine the height and review the selections of materials and type
of improvement to be used.
D. Double Frontage Lots. Double frontage lots are not permitted, except:
l. Where lots back upon- a primary street, and in such instances,
vehicular and pedestrian access between the lots and the primary
streets is prohibited; and
2. Where topographic or other conditions render subdividing
otherwise unreasonable, such double frontage lots shall have an
additional depth of at least twenty (20) feet in order to allow
for a protective screen planting on one frontage.
E. Lots Abutting a Water Course. Lots abutting a water course,
drainageway, channel, or stream shall have an additional depth or
width as recommended by the Village Engineer and approved by the
Village Board to provide an acceptable building site.
F. Preservation of Natural Features. In the subdivision of an; land, due
re~ard shall be given to the preservation of natural features, such as
trees, water courses, historical landmarks, and similar communit
assets, •hfch ff preserved, would add to the attractiveness and V!lue
of the subdivision, nei9hborhood, or the community as a whole. T'1e
Village Engineer shall include in its report recommendations to the
Plan Commission, its conclusions as to compliance.
